description: From French tarif, from Italian tariffa, from Ottoman Turkish تعرفه‎ (ta'rife), from Persian تعرفه‎ (ta'refe), from Arabic تَعْرِفَة‎ (taʕrifa, “tariff, rate”), from the root ع ر ف‎ (ʕ-r-f).

entries.meaning: A system of government-imposed duties levied on imported or exported goods; a list of such duties, or the duties themselves.
A schedule of rates, fees or prices.
examples: There is a tariff in every carriage, and most of them also have taxometers.

entries.meaning: (Britain) A sentence determined according to a scale of standard penalties for certain categories of crime.

verbs.description: tariff (third-person singular simple present tariffs, present participle tariffing, simple past and past participle tariffed)
